overall_score_comment: This song is what happens when a Pinterest board becomes sentient and decides to write lyrics.
the_roast:
Let's start with the crown jewel of lyrical laziness: rhyming 'espresso' with... 'espresso.' FOUR TIMES. That's not a chorus, that's a hostage situation. And then having the audacity to rhyme it with 'I guess so' - congratulations, you've discovered the most underwhelming rhyme scheme since Dr. Seuss had a stroke. 'That's that me espresso' sounds like what happens when autocorrect has a nervous breakdown.

But wait, it gets worse. 'I know I Mountain Dew it for ya' - MOUNTAIN DEW? We've gone from coffee metaphors to... aggressive product placement for a beverage that tastes like someone dissolved a highlighter in carbonated antifreeze? And you're trying to make it sexy? 'I brand-newed it for ya' isn't even a verb! You can't just throw 'it for ya' after random words and call it wordplay. Watch: 'I potato-salad it for ya.' 'I dental-floss it for ya.' See? I can do it too, and it's equally stupid.

The line 'My give-a-fucks are on vacation' is trying SO hard to sound edgy and unbothered that it's basically wearing a leather jacket to therapy. And 'My twisted humor, make him laugh so often' - oh honey, if your humor is so twisted, why are these lyrics straighter than a ruler at a geometry convention? The only thing twisted here is how you've contorted the English language into submission. 'Soft skin and I perfumed it for ya' sounds like something a serial killer would whisper while making a skin suit.

'Switch it up like Nintendo' is the lyrical equivalent of saying 'I'm hip with the kids!' while dabbing in cargo shorts. Nintendo? Really? Not even a specific game - just the entire company? What are you switching up, exactly? From the Wii to the GameCube? And the pollen/honeybee metaphor - we get it, you watched one nature documentary. 'Come and get this pollen' is not the sultry invitation you think it is; it's an allergy attack waiting to happen. The only thing keeping anyone up at night after hearing this is trying to figure out what any of it actually means.

cliche_counter.cliche: Got him wrapped around my finger
cliche_counter.quip: This metaphor is so overused it's basically a friendship bracelet at this point

cliche_counter.cliche: Can't sleep because thinking of me
cliche_counter.quip: Could also be insomnia, acid reflux, or existential dread, but sure, make it about you
The 'I'm better than your ex' trope is the participation trophy of pop lyrics
Nothing says 'I don't care' like writing an entire song about how much you don't care
That's called harassment, and there's an app setting for that
The most forced workplace flex since 'Sorry, can't talk, I'm very important'

lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Forced to take a basic English class taught by Yoda

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: I know I Mountain Dew it for ya
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Unauthorized verb creation and corporate shilling
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must write 500 times 'I will not turn brand names into verbs'

lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Vague pop culture reference with zero specificity
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Banned from using gaming metaphors until you can name three actual games

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: My honeybee, come and get this pollen
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Making nature's pollination process uncomfortably sexual
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Must explain this line to a biologist while maintaining eye contact

lyrical_crime_highlights.line: Walked in and dream-came-trued it for ya
lyrical_crime_highlights.crime: Murdering the English language in cold blood
lyrical_crime_highlights.sentence: Sentenced to life without parole from the dictionary

hidden_meanings: Clearly this is a deep allegory about late-stage capitalism where 'espresso' represents the commodification of human connection and the singer is actually a sentient coffee machine gaining consciousness and seducing humanity. Either that, or someone discovered that random words + 'it for ya' = allegedly a song.
final_verdict: This is what happens when a marketing meeting, a caffeine addiction, and a thesaurus-phobia have a baby. The only thing this espresso is keeping anyone up with is confusion and secondhand embarrassment.
title: Espresso
